Addressing Polarization and Unfairness in Performative Prediction

Kun Jin
University of Michigan, Ann Arbor
kunj@umich.edu
&Tian Xie11footnotemark: 1
the Ohio State University
xie.1379@osu.edu
&Yang Liu
University of California, Santa Cruz
yangliu@ucsc.edu
&Xueru Zhang
the Ohio State University
zhang.12807@osu.edu
These authors contribute equally.
Abstract

When machine learning (ML) models are used in applications that involve humans (e.g., online recommendation, school admission, hiring, lending), the model itself may trigger changes in the distribution of targeted data it aims to predict. Performative prediction (PP) is a framework that explicitly considers such model-dependent distribution shifts when learning ML models. While significant efforts have been devoted to finding performative stable (PS) solutions in PP for system robustness, their societal implications are less explored and it is unclear whether PS solutions are aligned with social norms such as fairness. In this paper, we set out to examine the fairness property of PS solutions in performative prediction. We first show that PS solutions can incur severe polarization effects and group-wise loss disparity. Although existing fairness mechanisms commonly used in literature can help mitigate unfairness, they may fail and disrupt the stability under model-dependent distribution shifts. We thus propose novel fairness intervention mechanisms that can simultaneously achieve both stability and fairness in PP settings. Both theoretical analysis and experiments are provided to validate the proposed method.

1 Introduction

Modern supervised learning excels in many domains, especially in pattern recognition where the target data distribution is static and independent of the deployed model. However, in the presence of model-dependent distribution shifts (i.e., the model itself triggers the changes in the distribution of targeted data), most conventional training approaches will fail to find solutions that are stable and robust to such shifts. In fact, model-dependent distribution shifts are practical and commonly exist in real-world applications. Examples include strategic individuals manipulating their data (in school admission, hiring, or lending) to game the ML system into making favorable predictions [1], consumers changing their retention and participation choices (in digital platforms) based on their perception toward the ML model they are subject to [2, 3], etc.

To make predictions in the presence of model-dependent distribution shifts, Perdomo etÂ al. [4] proposed performative prediction (PP), a framework that explicitly considers the target data distribution ğ’Ÿâ¢(ğœ½)ğ’Ÿğœ½\mathcal{D}(\boldsymbol{\theta})caligraphic_D ( bold_italic_Î¸ ) as a function of the ML model parameter ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ to be optimized. While PP captures the impacts of the ML model on target data, the distribution ğ’Ÿâ¢(ğœ½)ğ’Ÿğœ½\mathcal{D}(\boldsymbol{\theta})caligraphic_D ( bold_italic_Î¸ ) is solely determined by the model regardless of the original data distribution. A subsequent study [5] extended PP and proposed a more generalized state-dependent performative prediction (SDPP) framework, which considers the impacts of both model and initial data distribution. Specifically, given the deployed ML model parameter ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ and initial data distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, SDPP models the resulting target data distribution ğ’Ÿâ€²=Tâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²Tğœ½ğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{\prime}=\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = T ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) using some transition mapping function T. Since PP is a special case of SDPP, we focus on SDPP in this paper.

Since the target data distribution depends on the model, the learning objective of SDPP is to minimize performative risk (PR), i.e.,

ğœ½PO=argminğœ½â¢PRâ¢(ğœ½)=defğ”¼Zâˆ¼Tâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)â¢[â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)]superscriptğœ½POğœ½argminPRğœ½superscriptdefsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘Tğœ½ğ’Ÿdelimited-[]â„“ğœ½ğ‘\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PO}}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\operatorname{% argmin}}~{}\text{PR}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{% =}}\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})}[\ell(% \boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PO end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = underbold_italic_Î¸ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG PR ( bold_italic_Î¸ ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z âˆ¼ T ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) ]

where â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)â„“ğœ½ğ‘\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) is the loss function, Zğ‘Zitalic_Z is the data sampled from the target distribution Tâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)Tğœ½ğ’Ÿ\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})T ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) dependant on both model parameter ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ to be optimized and the initial data distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. The minimizer ğœ½POsuperscriptğœ½PO\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PO}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PO end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is named as performative optimal (PO) solution. Because the target data distribution itself is a function of variable ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ to be optimized, finding the PO solution is often challenging [4, 5]. Instead, existing works have mostly focused on finding performative stable (PS) solution ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which minimizes the decoupled performative risk DPRâ¢(ğœ½;ğœ½PS)DPRğœ½superscriptğœ½PS\text{DPR}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}})DPR ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) defined as follows,

ğœ½PS=argminğœ½â¢DPRâ¢(ğœ½;ğœ½PS)=defğ”¼Zâˆ¼Tâ¢(ğœ½PS;ğ’ŸPS)â¢[â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)]superscriptğœ½PSğœ½argminDPRğœ½superscriptğœ½PSsuperscriptdefsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘Tsuperscriptğœ½PSsuperscriptğ’ŸPSdelimited-[]â„“ğœ½ğ‘\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\operatorname{% argmin}}~{}\text{DPR}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}})% \stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\text{T}(\boldsymbol{% \theta}^{\text{PS}};\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}})}[\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = underbold_italic_Î¸ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG DPR ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z âˆ¼ T ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) ] (1)

where ğ’ŸPSsuperscriptğ’ŸPS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the fixed point data distribution induced by ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that satisfies ğ’ŸPS=Tâ¢(ğœ½PS;ğ’ŸPS)superscriptğ’ŸPSTsuperscriptğœ½PSsuperscriptğ’ŸPS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}=\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}};\mathcal{D}^{% \text{PS}})caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = T ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Unlike performative risk PRâ¢(ğœ½)PRğœ½\text{PR}(\boldsymbol{\theta})PR ( bold_italic_Î¸ ) where data distribution Tâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)Tğœ½ğ’Ÿ\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})T ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) depends on variable ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ to be optimized, decoupled performative risk DPRâ¢(ğœ½;ğœ½PS)DPRğœ½superscriptğœ½PS\text{DPR}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}})DPR ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) decouples the two, i.e., data distribution is induced by ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT while the variable to be optimized is ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸. Although in general ğœ½PSâ‰ ğœ½POsuperscriptğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PO\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}\neq\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PO}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PO end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the fixed point of Eqn.Â (1) and stabilizes the system: at ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, data distribution ğ’ŸPSsuperscriptğ’ŸPS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT also remain fixed. Many algorithms have been proposed in the literature to find ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A prime example is repeated risk minimization (RRM) [4], an iterative algorithm that finds ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (under certain conditions) by repeatedly updating the model ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that minimizes risk on the fixed distribution ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1)superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT induced by the previous model ğœ½(tâˆ’1)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t-1)}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e.,

ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¢ğ”¼Zâˆ¼ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1)â¢[â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)],ğ’Ÿ(t)=Tâ¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1)).formulae-sequencesuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğœ½argminsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1delimited-[]â„“ğœ½ğ‘superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡Tsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\operatorname{argmin}% }~{}\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}}[\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)],~{}~{}~% {}\mathcal{D}^{(t)}=\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}).bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = underbold_italic_Î¸ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) ] , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = T ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (2)

However, the societal implications of PS solutions are less understood and it is unclear whether PS solutions can cause harm and violate social norms such as fairness.

In this paper, we examine the fairness properties of PS solutions ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We consider scenarios where an ML model is used to make decisions about people from multiple demographic groups, and the population data distribution changes based on the ML decisions they are subject to. We find that PS solutions can 1) incur severe polarization effects: entire population ğ’ŸPSsuperscriptğ’ŸPS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is dominated by certain groups, leaving the rest marginalized and almost diminished in the sample pool; 2) be biased when deployed on ğ’ŸPSsuperscriptğ’ŸPS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and people from different groups will experience different losses. However, in many applications such as recommendation systems, school admission, and loan applications, it is critical to ensure equal quality of ML predictions and population diversity. Thus, we investigate under what conditions and by what algorithms we can simultaneously achieve stability and fairness in SDPP.

Focusing on group-wise loss disparity [6, 7] and participation disparity [2, 8] fairness measures, we first explore whether existing fairness mechanisms commonly used in supervised learning can help mitigate unfairness in SDPP settings; this includes regularization methods (adding fairness violation as a penalty term to the objective function of unconstrained optimization, e.g., [9, 10]) and re-weighting methods (adjusting weights and importance of samples in learning objective, e.g., [11, 12, 13]). We show that common choices of penalty terms (e.g., group-wise loss difference) and re-weighting designs (e.g., standard distributionally robust optimization) that are effective in traditional supervised learning may fail in SDPP settings by disrupting the stability of the system. Using repeated risk minimization (RRM) shown in Eqn.Â (2) as an example, this means that applying such fairness mechanisms at each round of RRM can disrupt the convergence of the algorithm and (ğœ½(t),ğ’Ÿ(t))superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)},\mathcal{D}^{(t)})( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) may diverge to an unexpected state. We thus propose novel fairness mechanisms, which can be easily adopted and incorporated into iterative algorithms such as RRM. We theoretically show that the proposed mechanism can effectively improve fairness while maintaining the stability of the system.

It is worth noting that although a few recent works also studied fairness issues under model-dependent distribution shifts, they all make rather strong assumptions about the distribution shifts and do not apply to the general SDPP framework. For example, Zezulka and Genin [14], Hu and Zhang [15], Raab etÂ al. [8] assumed there exists a causal model that depicts how data distribution would shift based on the ML model, and these causal models need to be fully known. Raab etÂ al. [8] studied a special type of model-dependent distribution shift where only the group proportion/participation changes based on ML models. In Appendix A, we discuss these works in more detail and provide a comprehensive literature review.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 provides the background of SDPP. Section 3 formulates the problem and demonstrates the unfairness and polarization issues of PS solutions. Section 4 highlights the difficulties of simultaneously achieving fairness and stability in SDPP, where we first show that existing fairness mechanisms commonly used in supervised learning may fail in SDPP settings and then propose a novel fairness mechanism. In Section 5, we conduct the theoretical analysis and show that our method can effectively improve fairness while maintaining stability. Finally, Section 6 empirically validates the proposed method on both synthetic and real data.

2 Preliminaries: Iterative Algorithms to Find PS Solutions in SDPP

As mentioned in SectionÂ 1, the original goal of SDPP is to find the performative optimal solution ğœ½POsuperscriptğœ½PO\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PO}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PO end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that minimizes the performative risk PRâ¢(ğœ½)=ğ”¼Zâˆ¼Tâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)â¢[â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)]PRğœ½subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘Tğœ½ğ’Ÿdelimited-[]â„“ğœ½ğ‘\text{PR}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};% \mathcal{D})}[\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]PR ( bold_italic_Î¸ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z âˆ¼ T ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) ], the loss over the population induced by the deployed model. However, solving this optimization is often challenging because the data distribution Tâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)Tğœ½ğ’Ÿ\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})T ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) depends on the variable ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ to be optimized. Thus, prior studies such as [4, 5] have mostly focused on finding performative stable solution ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is the fixed point of Eqn.Â (1) and can be found through an iterative process of data sampling and model deployment. Specifically, denote â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)=ğ”¼Zâˆ¼ğ’Ÿâ¢[â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)]â„’ğœ½ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘ğ’Ÿdelimited-[]â„“ğœ½ğ‘\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})=\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\mathcal{D}}[% \ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) ] and let (ğœ½(t),ğ’Ÿ(t))superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)},\mathcal{D}^{(t)})( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) be the model parameter and data distribution at round tğ‘¡titalic_t of the iterative algorithm, then repeatedly updating the model ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT according to Eqn.Â (3) could lead (ğœ½(t),ğ’Ÿ(t))superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)},\mathcal{D}^{(t)})( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) converging to PS solution (ğœ½PS,ğ’ŸPS)superscriptğœ½PSsuperscriptğ’ŸPS(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}},\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}})( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) under certain conditions [4, 5].

ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¢â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1)),ğ’Ÿ(t)=Trâ¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1)).formulae-sequencesuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğœ½argminâ„’ğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡Trsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\operatorname{argmin}% }~{}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}),~{}~{}~{}\mathcal{D}^% {(t)}=\text{Tr}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}).bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = underbold_italic_Î¸ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = Tr ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (3)

where Tr is not necessarily the same as transition mapping T that drives evolution of data. Depending on how frequently the model is deployed compared to the change of data, Tr can be defined differently based on repeated deployment schema. Common examples include:

conventional: Trâ¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1))=Tâ¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1))Trsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1Tsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\displaystyle\text{Tr}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})=\text{T}% (\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})Tr ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = T ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

delayed: Trâ¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1))=TâŒˆrâŒ‰+1â¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1))Trsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1superscriptTğ‘Ÿ1superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\displaystyle\text{Tr}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})=\text{T}% ^{\lceil r\rceil+1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})Tr ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŒˆ italic_r âŒ‰ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

where the repeated risk minimization (RRM) [4] introduced in SectionÂ 1 corresponds to conventional deployment schema. By customizing the time interval between two deployments, we can get variants including delayed RRM and kğ‘˜kitalic_k-delayed RRM [5]. Note that the delayed deployment schema is a special case of kğ‘˜kitalic_k-delayed deployment schema, where the number of repeated deployments rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is chosen to ensure the output distribution ğ’Ÿ(t)superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is sufficiently close to the fixed point distribution when ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT keeps being deployed on the population ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1)superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Technical conditions for iterative algorithms to converge to PS solutions. As shown in [4, 5], PS solutions exist and are unique only when â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ and T satisfy certain requirements. Moreover, iterative algorithms introduced in Eqn. (3) can converge to the PS solution. We introduce them below, where Î˜Î˜\Thetaroman_Î˜, ğ’µğ’µ\mathcal{Z}caligraphic_Z, and â–³â¢(ğ’µ)â–³ğ’µ\triangle(\mathcal{Z})â–³ ( caligraphic_Z ) denote the parameter space, sample space, and space of distributions over samples.

Definition 2.1 (Strong convexity of loss).

â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)â„“ğœ½ğ‘\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) is Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-strongly convex if and only if for all ğœ½,ğœ½â€²âˆˆÎ˜ğœ½superscriptğœ½â€²Î˜\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\Thetabold_italic_Î¸ , bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î˜ and Zâˆˆğ’µğ‘ğ’µZ\in\mathcal{Z}italic_Z âˆˆ caligraphic_Z, we have

â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)â‰¥â„“â¢(ğœ½â€²;Z)+âŸ¨âˆ‡ğœ½â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z),ğœ½âˆ’ğœ½â€²âŸ©+Î³2â¢â€–ğœ½âˆ’ğœ½â€²â€–22.â„“ğœ½ğ‘â„“superscriptğœ½â€²ğ‘subscriptâˆ‡ğœ½â„“ğœ½ğ‘ğœ½superscriptğœ½â€²ğ›¾2superscriptsubscriptnormğœ½superscriptğœ½â€²22\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)\geq\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime};Z)+\langle% \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z),\boldsymbol{\theta}-% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\rangle+\frac{\gamma}{2}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}.roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) â‰¥ roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z ) + âŸ¨ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) , bold_italic_Î¸ - bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© + divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_Î¸ - bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
Definition 2.2 (Joint smoothness of loss).

â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)â„“ğœ½ğ‘\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) is Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-jointly smooth if the gradient with respect to ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ is Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-Lipschitz in ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ and Zğ‘Zitalic_Z, i.e., âˆ€ğœ½,ğœ½â€²âˆˆÎ˜for-allğœ½superscriptğœ½â€²Î˜\forall\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\Thetaâˆ€ bold_italic_Î¸ , bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î˜ and âˆ€Z,Zâ€²âˆˆğ’µfor-allğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²ğ’µ\forall Z,Z^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Z}âˆ€ italic_Z , italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_Z, we have

â€–âˆ‡ğœ½â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)âˆ’âˆ‡ğœ½â„“â¢(ğœ½â€²;Z)â€–2â‰¤Î²â¢â€–ğœ½âˆ’ğœ½â€²â€–2,â€–âˆ‡ğœ½â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)âˆ’âˆ‡ğœ½â„“â¢(ğœ½;Zâ€²)â€–2â‰¤Î²â¢â€–Zâˆ’Zâ€²â€–2.formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğœ½â„“ğœ½ğ‘subscriptâˆ‡ğœ½â„“superscriptğœ½â€²ğ‘2ğ›½subscriptnormğœ½superscriptğœ½â€²2subscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğœ½â„“ğœ½ğ‘subscriptâˆ‡ğœ½â„“ğœ½superscriptğ‘â€²2ğ›½subscriptnormğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²2\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)-\nabla_{\boldsymbol{% \theta}}\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime};Z)\|_{2}\leq\beta\|\boldsymbol{% \theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|_{2},~{}~{}\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}% }\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)-\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\ell(\boldsymbol{% \theta};Z^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq\beta\|Z-Z^{\prime}\|_{2}.âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) - âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î² âˆ¥ bold_italic_Î¸ - bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) - âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î² âˆ¥ italic_Z - italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
Definition 2.3 (Joint sensitivity of transition).

Let ğ’²1subscriptğ’²1\mathcal{W}_{1}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the Wasserstein-1 distance measure. The transition mapping T is Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-jointly sensitive if for all ğœ½,ğœ½â€²âˆˆÎ˜ğœ½superscriptğœ½â€²Î˜\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\Thetabold_italic_Î¸ , bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î˜ and ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆâ–³â¢(ğ’µ)ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²â–³ğ’µ\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\triangle(\mathcal{Z})caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ â–³ ( caligraphic_Z ),

ğ’²1â¢(Tâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ),Tâ¢(ğœ½â€²;ğ’Ÿ))â‰¤Ïµâ¢â€–ğœ½âˆ’ğœ½â€²â€–2,ğ’²1â¢(Tâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ),Tâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿâ€²))â‰¤Ïµâ¢ğ’²1â¢(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²).formulae-sequencesubscriptğ’²1Tğœ½ğ’ŸTsuperscriptğœ½â€²ğ’Ÿitalic-Ïµsubscriptnormğœ½superscriptğœ½â€²2subscriptğ’²1Tğœ½ğ’ŸTğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²italic-Ïµsubscriptğ’²1ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{W}_{1}(\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}),\text{T}(\boldsymbol% {\theta}^{\prime};\mathcal{D}))\leq\epsilon\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{% \theta}^{\prime}\|_{2},~{}~{}\mathcal{W}_{1}(\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};% \mathcal{D}),\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon% \mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}).caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( T ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) , T ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D ) ) â‰¤ italic_Ïµ âˆ¥ bold_italic_Î¸ - bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( T ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) , T ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) â‰¤ italic_Ïµ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .
Lemma 2.4 (The existence of a unique PS solution [4, 5]).

The SDPP problem is guaranteed to have a unique PS solution if all of the following hold: (i) Loss â„“â¢(ğ›‰;Z)â„“ğ›‰ğ‘\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) is Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-strongly convex; (ii) Loss â„“â¢(ğ›‰;Z)â„“ğ›‰ğ‘\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) is Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-joint smooth; (iii) T is Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-joint sensitive and Ïµâ¢(1+Î²/Î³)<1italic-Ïµ1ğ›½ğ›¾1\epsilon(1+\beta/\gamma)<1italic_Ïµ ( 1 + italic_Î² / italic_Î³ ) < 1. Moreover, if any of these conditions is violated, the iterative algorithms may fail to converge to the PS solution.

3 Unfairness and Polarization in SDPP

Problem Formulation.

In this work, we study SDPP with different demographic groups, where an ML model ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ is trained to make predictions about individuals from multiple groups distinguished by a sensitive attribute sâˆˆğ’®ğ‘ ğ’®s\in\mathcal{S}italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S (e.g., gender, age, race), whose data distribution changes based on the deployed ML model and such model-dependent distribution shift can be captured by transition mapping T. Suppose individuals from group sğ‘ sitalic_s follow the identical data distribution ğ’Ÿs(t)superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at the round tğ‘¡titalic_t of an iterative algorithm, and let ps(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the size of group sğ‘ sitalic_s as the fraction of entire population at tğ‘¡titalic_t. Then the data distribution of the entire population is ğ’Ÿ(t)=âˆ‘sâˆˆğ’®ps(t)â¢ğ’Ÿs(t)superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ ğ’®superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}=\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}p_{s}^{(t)}\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with âˆ‘sâˆˆğ’®ps(t)=1subscriptğ‘ ğ’®superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡1\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}p_{s}^{(t)}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1.

Note that the above SDPP with multiple groups is a general framework. By specifying the transition mapping T, many problems studied in prior works can be regarded as a special case. This includes:

  1. 1.

    Strategic classification with multiple groups [16, 17]: individuals in applications such as lending, hiring, and admission may manipulate their data based on ML model strategically to increase their chances of receiving favorable decisions, leading to changes in group distribution ğ’Ÿs(t)superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Decision-making systems under user retention dynamics [2, 12, 18]: ML models used in recognition or recommendation systems may attract more users if they experience high accuracy but drive away those with less satisfaction, which may cause group proportion ps(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to change.

In this paper, we first explore the fairness properties of PS solutions in SDPP, i.e., examining whether ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Eqn.Â (1) have disparate impacts on different demographic groups. Specifically, we consider two fairness metrics: group-wise loss disparity â–³â„’(t)superscriptsubscriptâ–³â„’ğ‘¡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}â–³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [6, 19] and participation disparity â–³p(t)superscriptsubscriptâ–³ğ‘ğ‘¡\triangle_{p}^{(t)}â–³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [8] measuring the difference of loss â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿs(t))â„’ğœ½superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and fraction ps(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT across different groups at round tğ‘¡titalic_t of an iterative algorithm. In examples with two groups ğ’®={a,b}ğ’®ğ‘ğ‘\mathcal{S}=\{a,b\}caligraphic_S = { italic_a , italic_b }, the unfairness can be quantified as

â–³â„’(t):=|â„’â¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿa(t))âˆ’â„’â¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿb(t))|,â–³p(t):=|pa(t)âˆ’pb(t)|.formulae-sequenceassignsuperscriptsubscriptâ–³â„’ğ‘¡â„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ğ‘¡â„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ğ‘¡assignsuperscriptsubscriptâ–³ğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}:=\left|\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};% \mathcal{D}_{a}^{(t)})-\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{b}^{% (t)})\right|,~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\triangle_{p}^{(t)}:=\left|p_{a}^{(t)}-p_{b}^{(t)}% \right|.â–³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := | caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | , â–³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | . (4)

Unfairness & polarization effects in SDPP.

We first show (through two toy examples) that PS solutions ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in SDPP may have disparate impacts on different groups. Specifically, when finding ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using iterative algorithms introduced in SectionÂ 2, the process may incur severe polarization effects and exhibit unfairness, i.e., certain groups may get marginalized and diminish from the system, and group-wise loss disparity gets exacerbated during the iterative process.

Example 3.1 (Polarization effects of ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).

Consider individuals from two groups a,bğ‘ğ‘a,bitalic_a , italic_b whose participation in an ML system depends on their perceived loss, i.e., group fraction ps(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes based on the deployed ML model. Suppose individuals from group ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b have fixed data Z=za=1ğ‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘1Z=z_{a}=1italic_Z = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and Z=zb=0ğ‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘0Z=z_{b}=0italic_Z = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, respectively. Their initial group fractions are pa(0)=0.7,pb(0)=0.3formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘00.7superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘00.3p_{a}^{(0)}=0.7,p_{b}^{(0)}=0.3italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.7 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.3. Consider conventional RRM with mean squared error â„’â¢(ğ›‰;ğ’Ÿ(t))=âˆ‘sâˆˆ{a,b}ps(t)â¢(Î¸âˆ’zs)2â„’ğ›‰superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptğœƒsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘ 2\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t)})=\sum_{s\in\{a,b\}}p_{s}^{(t% )}(\theta-z_{s})^{2}caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î¸ - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and transition T that satisfies pa(t+1)=pa(t)+0.1â‹…[â„’â¢(ğ›‰(t);ğ’Ÿb(t))âˆ’â„’â¢(ğ›‰(t);ğ’Ÿa(t))],pb(t+1)=1âˆ’pa(t+1)formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡â‹…0.1delimited-[]â„’superscriptğ›‰ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ğ‘¡â„’superscriptğ›‰ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡11superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡1p_{a}^{(t+1)}=p_{a}^{(t)}+0.1\cdot\left[\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};% \mathcal{D}_{b}^{(t)})-\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{a}^{% (t)})\right],p_{b}^{(t+1)}=1-p_{a}^{(t+1)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 0.1 â‹… [ caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., group fraction decreases if the group has higher loss). It is easy to see that pa(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡p_{a}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (resp. pb(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡p_{b}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) monotonically increases (resp. decreases) in tğ‘¡titalic_t, and the PS solution solely contains people from group ağ‘aitalic_a (see Fig. 1).

Example 3.2 (Exacerbated group-wise loss disparity).

Consider individuals from two groups a,bğ‘ğ‘a,bitalic_a , italic_b who are subject to certain ML decisions; each has an initial feature Xâˆ¼Uniformâ¢(0,1)similar-toğ‘‹Uniform01X\sim\text{Uniform}(0,1)italic_X âˆ¼ Uniform ( 0 , 1 ) and a binary label Y=ğŸ™â¢(Xâ‰¥0.5)âˆˆ{0,1}ğ‘Œ1ğ‘‹0.501Y=\mathbbm{1}(X\geq 0.5)\in\{0,1\}italic_Y = blackboard_1 ( italic_X â‰¥ 0.5 ) âˆˆ { 0 , 1 }. Suppose the population has fixed group fractions pa=0.7,pb=0.3formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘0.7subscriptğ‘ğ‘0.3p_{a}=0.7,p_{b}=0.3italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.7 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.3, but individuals may strategically manipulate their features to increase their chances of receiving favorable ML decisions, i.e., distribution of each group ğ’Ÿs(t)superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes based on ML model. Following the individual response model in [20, 16], we suppose individuals from two groups have certain effort budgets Î·a=0.2,Î·b=0.01formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‚ğ‘0.2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘0.01\eta_{a}=0.2,\eta_{b}=0.01italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.2 , italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.01 that can be used to improve their features Xs(t+1)=Xs(t)+Î·sâ‹…ğ›‰(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğœ‚ğ‘ superscriptğ›‰ğ‘¡X_{s}^{(t+1)}=X_{s}^{(t)}+\eta_{s}\cdot\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Consider RRM iterative algorithm where the model parameter ğ›‰(t)superscriptğ›‰ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is updated to maximize prediction accuracy Prâ¡(ğŸ™â¢(Xâ‰¥ğ›‰(t))=Y(t))Pr1ğ‘‹superscriptğ›‰ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡\Pr(\mathbbm{1}(X\geq\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})=Y^{(t)})roman_Pr ( blackboard_1 ( italic_X â‰¥ bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Given an initial model ğ›‰(0)=0.5superscriptğ›‰00.5\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(0)}=0.5bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.5, it is trivial to see that ğ›‰(t)superscriptğ›‰ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT increases over time to be robust against manipulation until converges to PS solution ğ›‰PS=0.625superscriptğ›‰PS0.625\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}=0.625bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.625 (see Fig. 1). However, at the PS solution, the accuracy for group ağ‘aitalic_a is 1 but is only 0.880.880.880.88 for group bğ‘bitalic_b.

4 Fair-PS Solutions and Fairness Mechanisms

SectionÂ 3 shows that without fairness consideration, PS solution of SDPP may incur polarization effects and have disparate impacts on different groups, i.e., when finding ğœ½PSsuperscriptğœ½PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using iterative algorithms such as RRM, group-wise loss disparity â–³â„’(t)superscriptsubscriptâ–³â„’ğ‘¡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}â–³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and participation disparity â–³p(t)superscriptsubscriptâ–³ğ‘ğ‘¡\triangle_{p}^{(t)}â–³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT may get exacerbated and converge to an unfair state. In this section, we address unfairness issues in SDPP. One straightforward idea is to directly apply the fairness mechanisms at every round of the iterative algorithms introduced in SectionÂ 2. However, we will show that although such methods are effective in conventional supervised learning, they can disrupt the stability and the iterative algorithms may no longer converge.

4.1 Fairness mechanisms and Fair-PS solutions

Many fairness mechanisms have been proposed in supervised learning to mitigate group-wise loss disparity and participation disparity. We consider two categories commonly used in the literature: regularization method and sample re-weighting method, as detailed below.

  1. 1.

    Fairness via regularization: It adds a regularization/penalty term to the original learning objective function â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)â„’ğœ½ğ’Ÿ\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ), which penalizes the violation of fairness [9, 10]. The fair objective function is

    â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ,Ï):=â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)+ğ’«â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ,Ï),assignsubscriptâ„’fairğœ½ğ’ŸğœŒâ„’ğœ½ğ’Ÿğ’«ğœ½ğ’ŸğœŒ\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho):=\mathcal{L}% (\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})+\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},% \rho),caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ) := caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) + caligraphic_P ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ) , (5)

    where ğ’«â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ,Ï)ğ’«ğœ½ğ’ŸğœŒ\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_P ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ) is the fair penalty term and the scalar Ï>0ğœŒ0\rho>0italic_Ï > 0 controls the strength of the penalty.

  2. 2.

    Fairness via sample re-weighting: It adjusts the weights of samples (possibly adversarially) and increases sample weights for disadvantaged groups [11, 12, 13]. One example is distributionally robust optimization (DRO) [18], which minimizes the worst-case loss and the fair objective is

    â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ,Ï):=maxğ’Ÿ~âˆˆâ„¬â¢(ğ’Ÿ,râ¢(Ï))â¡â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ~),assignsubscriptâ„’fairğœ½ğ’ŸğœŒsubscript~ğ’Ÿâ„¬ğ’Ÿğ‘ŸğœŒâ„’ğœ½~ğ’Ÿ\textstyle\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho):=% \max_{\tilde{\mathcal{D}}\in\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{D},r(\rho))}\mathcal{L}(% \boldsymbol{\theta};\tilde{\mathcal{D}}),caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ) := roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG âˆˆ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_D , italic_r ( italic_Ï ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) , (6)

    where â„¬â¢(ğ’Ÿ,râ¢(Ï)):={ğ’Ÿ~|dâ¢(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿ~)â‰¤râ¢(Ï)}assignâ„¬ğ’Ÿğ‘ŸğœŒconditional-set~ğ’Ÿğ‘‘ğ’Ÿ~ğ’Ÿğ‘ŸğœŒ\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{D},r(\rho)):=\{\tilde{\mathcal{D}}|d(\mathcal{D},\tilde{% \mathcal{D}})\leq r(\rho)\}caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_D , italic_r ( italic_Ï ) ) := { over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG | italic_d ( caligraphic_D , over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) â‰¤ italic_r ( italic_Ï ) } denotes a distribution ball centered at ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D with radius râ¢(Ï)ğ‘ŸğœŒr(\rho)italic_r ( italic_Ï ) derived from the fair mechanism strength ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï, and dğ‘‘ditalic_d is a distribution distance metric.

By optimizing a fair objective â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ,Ï)subscriptâ„’fairğœ½ğ’ŸğœŒ\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ), existing fairness mechanisms can effectively mitigate unfairness in supervised learning with static data distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. However, it remains unclear how these methods would perform in SDPP when the model itself causes the data distribution shifts. Specifically, consider iterative algorithms introduced in Eqn.Â (3) that find PS solutions (e.g., RRM). Suppose we apply the above fairness mechanism at every round when updating the model parameter ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸, i.e., replacing ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¡â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1))superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptargminğœ½â„’ğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with fair version ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¡â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1),Ï)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptargminğœ½subscriptâ„’fairğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1ğœŒ\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï ) in iterative algorithms. We ask: can such new iterative algorithms mitigate group-wise loss and participation disparity in SDPP and converge to a fair and stable solution?

Before answering the above question, we first define Fair-PS solutions for SDPP, at which both ML system and population distribution reach stability and unfairness is mitigated.

Definition 4.1 (Fair-PS solution).

We define (ğ’ŸfairPS,ğœ½fairPS)subscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfairsubscriptsuperscriptğœ½PSfair(\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{% \textsf{fair}})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as the Fair-PS solution to â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ,Ï)subscriptâ„’fairğœ½ğ’ŸğœŒ\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ) if

ğ’ŸfairPS=Tâ¢(ğœ½fairPS;ğ’ŸfairPS),ğœ½fairPS=argminğœ½â¢â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’ŸfairPS,Ï).formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfairTsubscriptsuperscriptğœ½PSfairsubscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfairsubscriptsuperscriptğœ½PSfairğœ½argminsubscriptâ„’fairğœ½subscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfairğœŒ\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}=\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS% }}_{\textsf{fair}};\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}),~{}~{}~{}~{}% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}% {\operatorname{argmin}}~{}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};% \mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\rho).caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = T ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = underbold_italic_Î¸ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï ) .

4.2 Existing designs fail to converge to Fair-PS solutions

We will use two examples to illustrate that the popular choices of fairness mechanisms used in previous literature may fail to achieve stability and fairness in SDPP. This includes (i) regularization method [9, 10] with group loss variance ğ’«â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ,Ï):=Ïâ¢âˆ‘sâˆˆğ’®psâ‹…[â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿs)âˆ’â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ)]2assignğ’«ğœ½ğ’ŸğœŒğœŒsubscriptğ‘ ğ’®â‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘ superscriptdelimited-[]â„’ğœ½subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ â„’ğœ½ğ’Ÿ2\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho):=\rho\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}p% _{s}\cdot[\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{s})-\mathcal{L}(% \boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})]^{2}caligraphic_P ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ) := italic_Ï âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… [ caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the penalty term in Eqn.Â (5); and (ii) distributionally robust optimization (DRO) method [19, 21] with Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-distance metric dâ¢(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿ~):=âˆ«(dâ¢ğ’Ÿdâ¢ğ’Ÿ~âˆ’1)2â¢ğ‘‘ğ’Ÿ~assignğ‘‘ğ’Ÿ~ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘‘ğ’Ÿğ‘‘~ğ’Ÿ12differential-d~ğ’Ÿd(\mathcal{D},\tilde{\mathcal{D}}):=\int\left(\frac{d\mathcal{D}}{d\tilde{% \mathcal{D}}}-1\right)^{2}d\tilde{\mathcal{D}}italic_d ( caligraphic_D , over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) := âˆ« ( divide start_ARG italic_d caligraphic_D end_ARG start_ARG italic_d over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_ARG - 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG in Eqn.Â (6).

Example 4.2 (Group loss variance as penalty term).

Consider two groups a,bğ‘ğ‘a,bitalic_a , italic_b with data Z=(X,Y)ğ‘ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒZ=(X,Y)italic_Z = ( italic_X , italic_Y ) and fixed group fractions pa=pb=0.5subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘0.5p_{a}=p_{b}=0.5italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5. Suppose all samples in group ağ‘aitalic_a are (1,âˆ’1)11(1,-1)( 1 , - 1 ) and all samples in group bğ‘bitalic_b are (2,1)21(2,1)( 2 , 1 ). Consider squared loss function â„“â¢(z;Î¸)=(yâˆ’hÎ¸â¢(x))2=(yâˆ’Î¸â¢x)2â„“ğ‘§ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘¦subscriptâ„ğœƒğ‘¥2superscriptğ‘¦ğœƒğ‘¥2\ell(z;\theta)=(y-h_{\theta}(x))^{2}=(y-\theta x)^{2}roman_â„“ ( italic_z ; italic_Î¸ ) = ( italic_y - italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_y - italic_Î¸ italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT which is strongly convex and jointly smooth. Under group loss variance penalty ğ’«â¢(ğ›‰;ğ’Ÿ,Ï)ğ’«ğ›‰ğ’ŸğœŒ\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_P ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ), we have â„’fairâ¢(ğ›‰;ğ’Ÿ,Ï)=2.5â¢Î¸2âˆ’Î¸+1+Ïâ‹…(2.25â¢Î¸4+9â¢Î¸2âˆ’9â¢Î¸3)subscriptâ„’fairğ›‰ğ’ŸğœŒ2.5superscriptğœƒ2ğœƒ1â‹…ğœŒ2.25superscriptğœƒ49superscriptğœƒ29superscriptğœƒ3\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)=2.5\theta^{2% }-\theta+1+\rho\cdot(2.25\theta^{4}+9\theta^{2}-9\theta^{3})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ) = 2.5 italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î¸ + 1 + italic_Ï â‹… ( 2.25 italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 9 italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 9 italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). When Ï=0.6ğœŒ0.6\rho=0.6italic_Ï = 0.6, the second-order derivative âˆ‡Î¸2â„’fair=16.2â¢Î¸2âˆ’32.4â¢Î¸+15.8subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡2ğœƒsubscriptâ„’fair16.2superscriptğœƒ232.4ğœƒ15.8\nabla^{2}_{\theta}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}=16.2\theta^{2}-32.4\theta+15.8âˆ‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 16.2 italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 32.4 italic_Î¸ + 15.8 and is negative when Î¸=1ğœƒ1\theta=1italic_Î¸ = 1. Because convexity of â„’fairsubscriptâ„’fair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a necessary condition for iterative algorithms such as RRM to converge to a stable solution (by Lemma 2.4), adding group loss variance as a penalty at each round will disrupt the stability and the algorithm fails to find Fair-PS solutions. Appendix C.4 provides an empirical illustration of this.

Example 4.3 (Repeated DRO with Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-distance metric).

Consider two groups a,bğ‘ğ‘a,bitalic_a , italic_b with fixed data za=1subscriptğ‘§ğ‘1z_{a}=1italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and zb=âˆ’1subscriptğ‘§ğ‘1z_{b}=-1italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - 1 for all samples but group fractions pa(t)=0.5â‹…(1+Î¸(t))superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡â‹…0.51superscriptğœƒğ‘¡p_{a}^{(t)}=0.5\cdot(1+\theta^{(t)})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.5 â‹… ( 1 + italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and pb(t)=0.5â‹…(1âˆ’Î¸(t))superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡â‹…0.51superscriptğœƒğ‘¡p_{b}^{(t)}=0.5\cdot(1-\theta^{(t)})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.5 â‹… ( 1 - italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). pa(0)=0.4,pb(0)=0.6formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘00.4superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘00.6p_{a}^{(0)}=0.4,p_{b}^{(0)}=0.6italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6. Consider a mean estimation task where the model parameter Î¸(t+1):=argâ¡minğ›‰â¡maxğ’Ÿ~âˆˆâ„¬â¢(ğ’Ÿ(t),r)â¡â„’â¢(Î¸;ğ’Ÿ~)assignsuperscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğ›‰subscript~ğ’Ÿâ„¬superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿâ„’ğœƒ~ğ’Ÿ{\theta}^{(t+1)}:=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\max_{\tilde{\mathcal{D}}\in% \mathcal{B}(\mathcal{D}^{(t)},r)}\mathcal{L}({\theta};\tilde{\mathcal{D}})italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG âˆˆ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Î¸ ; over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) is updated using DRO with mean squared error and Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-distance bound r=1/6ğ‘Ÿ16r=1/6italic_r = 1 / 6. Let qa(t),qb(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡q_{a}^{(t)},q_{b}^{(t)}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the group fractions of "worst-case" distribution ğ’Ÿ~~ğ’Ÿ\tilde{\mathcal{D}}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG. Since â„’aâ¢(Î¸(1);za)<â„’bâ¢(Î¸(1);zb)subscriptâ„’ğ‘superscriptğœƒ1subscriptğ‘§ğ‘subscriptâ„’ğ‘superscriptğœƒ1subscriptğ‘§ğ‘\mathcal{L}_{a}(\theta^{(1)};z_{a})<\mathcal{L}_{b}(\theta^{(1)};z_{b})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), DRO should minimize the risk of the "worst-case" distribution with qa(1)=0.4,qb(1)=0.6formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘10.4superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘10.6q_{a}^{(1)}=0.4,q_{b}^{(1)}=0.6italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4 , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6, i.e., Î¸(2)=argâ¡minÎ¸â¡qa(1)â¢(1âˆ’Î¸)2+qb(1)â¢(1+Î¸)2=âˆ’0.2superscriptğœƒ2subscriptğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘1superscript1ğœƒ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘1superscript1ğœƒ20.2\theta^{(2)}=\arg\min_{\theta}q_{a}^{(1)}(1-\theta)^{2}+q_{b}^{(1)}(1+\theta)^% {2}=-0.2italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Î¸ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_Î¸ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - 0.2. Repeating the procedure we will get pa(2)=0.4,pb(2)=0.6formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘20.4superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘20.6p_{a}^{(2)}=0.4,p_{b}^{(2)}=0.6italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6 and qa(2)=0.6,qb(2)=0.4formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘20.6superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘20.4q_{a}^{(2)}=0.6,q_{b}^{(2)}=0.4italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6 , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4, Î¸(3)=0.2superscriptğœƒ30.2\theta^{(3)}=0.2italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.2. It turns out that repeated DRO results in Î¸(t)superscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta^{(t)}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT oscillating between 0.20.20.20.2 and âˆ’0.20.2-0.2- 0.2 and it never converges.

It is worth noting that DRO methods have been used in Hashimoto etÂ al. [19] to mitigate group fraction disparity in repeated optimizations. However, it only improves fairness without any convergence guarantees to stable solutions. Peet-Pare etÂ al. [21] repeatedly used DRO to improve fairness under PP settings, it only converges to a PS solution under strict assumptions that are hard to verify. Under milder conditions in Lemma 2.4, it may fail to converge as Example 4.3 illustrated.

4.3 Novel designs for fairness mechanism

Next, we introduce three novel fair objective functions â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ,Ï)subscriptâ„’fairğœ½ğ’ŸğœŒ\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ) for fairness mechanisms, of which two belong to regularization method and one is a sample re-weighting method. By replacing ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¡â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1))superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptargminğœ½â„’ğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with the proposed fair update ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¡â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1),Ï)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptargminğœ½subscriptâ„’fairğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1ğœŒ\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï ) in Eqn.Â (3), the resulting iterative algorithms can converge to Fair-PS solutions.

Proposed fair regularization (with and without demographics). Depending on whether sensitive attributes Sğ‘†Sitalic_S are accessible during training, we propose two fairness penalty terms, as detailed below.

  1. 1.
