  2. 2.

    Sample level fairness penalty without demographics: It updates model parameter ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at round tğ‘¡titalic_t as follows, which does not need the knowledge of sensitive attributes.

    ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¡â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1),Ï):=â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1))+Ïâ¢ğ”¼Zâˆ¼ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1)â¢[[â„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)]2].superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptargminğœ½subscriptâ„’fairğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1ğœŒassignâ„’ğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1ğœŒsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-[]â„“ğœ½ğ‘2\textstyle\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}% }\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho):=% \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})+\rho\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim% \mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}}\big{[}[\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]^{2}\big{]}.bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï ) := caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_Ï blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ [ roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] . (8)

Proposed fair sample re-weighting. It updates model parameter ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at round tğ‘¡titalic_t as follows.

ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¡â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1),Ï):=âˆ‘sâˆˆğ’®qs(tâˆ’1)â¢â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿs(tâˆ’1)),superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptargminğœ½subscriptâ„’fairğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1ğœŒassignsubscriptğ‘ ğ’®superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡1â„’ğœ½superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{% \theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},% \rho):=\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}q_{s}^{(t-1)}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};% \mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-1)}),bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï ) := âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (9)
withÂ â¢ğ’’(tâˆ’1)=[qs(tâˆ’1)]sâˆˆğ’®:=ğ’‘(tâˆ’1)+Ïâ¢ğ’(tâˆ’1)â€–ğ’‘(tâˆ’1)+Ïâ¢ğ’(tâˆ’1)â€–1â¢Â andÂ â¢ğ’(tâˆ’1):=[ps(tâˆ’1)â¢â„’â¢(ğœ½(tâˆ’1);ğ’Ÿs(tâˆ’2))]sâˆˆğ’®withÂ superscriptğ’’ğ‘¡1subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ’®assignsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1ğœŒsuperscriptğ’ğ‘¡1subscriptnormsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1ğœŒsuperscriptğ’ğ‘¡11Â andÂ superscriptğ’ğ‘¡1assignsubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡1â„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡2ğ‘ ğ’®\displaystyle\text{with }~{}\boldsymbol{q}^{(t-1)}=\left[q^{(t-1)}_{s}\right]_% {s\in\mathcal{S}}:=\frac{\boldsymbol{p}^{(t-1)}+\rho\boldsymbol{l}^{(t-1)}}{\|% \boldsymbol{p}^{(t-1)}+\rho\boldsymbol{l}^{(t-1)}\|_{1}}\text{ and }~{}% \boldsymbol{l}^{(t-1)}:=\left[p_{s}^{(t-1)}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t% -1)};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-2)})\right]_{s\in\mathcal{S}}with bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Ï bold_italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Ï bold_italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG and bold_italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

Unlike DRO methods in [22, 19] that require solving a min-max optimization at the current round, our re-weighting method only adjusts the weights for each group based on the group-wise losses in the previous round, which is more computationally efficient.

Comparison & discussion. Intuitively, compared to original â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1))â„’ğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), all three proposed fair objective functions â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1),Ï)subscriptâ„’fairğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1ğœŒ\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï ) improves fairness at each round by assigning more weights to disadvantaged groups/samples (i.e., the groups/samples experiencing higher losses) in the upcoming update. Indeed, both sample level fairness penalty and fair sample re-weighting can be regarded as modifications of group level fairness penalty.

Comparing Eqn.Â (7) and (8), the two penalty terms get more similar when most individual samples in the disadvantaged (resp. advantaged) groups are also similarly disadvantaged (resp. advantaged). This is more likely to happen when each demographic group has a distribution with a small variance. For example, if the distribution of each group is a point mass, Eqn. (7) and (8) are identical.

Comparing Eqn. (7) and (9), we can rewrite Eqn. (9) as the following:

â€–ğ’‘(tâˆ’1)+Ïâ¢ğ’(tâˆ’1)â€–1â¢â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1),Ï)=âˆ‘sâˆˆğ’®ps(tâˆ’1)â¢(1+Ï)â¢â„’â¢(ğœ½(tâˆ’1);ğ’Ÿs(tâˆ’2))â¢â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿs(tâˆ’1)).subscriptnormsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1ğœŒsuperscriptğ’ğ‘¡11subscriptâ„’fairğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1ğœŒsubscriptğ‘ ğ’®superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡11ğœŒâ„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡2â„’ğœ½superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡1\textstyle\|\boldsymbol{p}^{(t-1)}+\rho\boldsymbol{l}^{(t-1)}\|_{1}\mathcal{L}% _{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)=~{}\sum_{s\in% \mathcal{S}}p_{s}^{(t-1)}(1+\rho)\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t-1)};% \mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-2)})\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-1)% }).âˆ¥ bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Ï bold_italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_Ï ) caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

We can see that the right-hand side will be a multiple of Eqn.Â (7) if we replace â„’â¢(ğœ½(tâˆ’1);ğ’Ÿs(tâˆ’2))â„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡2\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t-1)};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-2)})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿs(tâˆ’1))â„’ğœ½superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡1\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-1)})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). This means both equations yield the same Î¸(t)superscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta^{(t)}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when the population distribution does not change from tâˆ’2ğ‘¡2t-2italic_t - 2 to tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1italic_t - 1, suggesting that the two approaches become more similar when the sensitivity of the transition mapping T is smaller, or equivalently, the distribution shift is milder. Finally, we also discuss designing fair objective functions generally in App. B.4.

5 Theoretical Analysis

Next, we show that by replacing update ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¡â„’â¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1))superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptargminğœ½â„’ğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in Eqn.Â (3) with the fair update ğœ½(t)=argminğœ½â¡â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1),Ï)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptargminğœ½subscriptâ„’fairğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1ğœŒ\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï ) we proposed in SectionÂ 4.3, Fair-PS solutions (DefinitionÂ 4.1) exist under certain conditions and the resulting iterative algorithms (see Algorithm 1) can converge to such Fair-PS solutions. We assume conditions in LemmaÂ 2.4 hold in this section and there exists a unique PS solution in the original SDPP problem.

We first define a parameter Î²~~ğ›½\tilde{\beta}over~ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG which will be frequently used in the theorems introduced below.

Î²~:={(2â¢Ïâ¢â„“Â¯+1)â¢Î²,for fair regularization method with group level (7) or sample level penalty (8)Â (Ïâ¢â„“Â¯+1)â¢Î²,for fair sample re-weighting method (9)Â assign~ğ›½cases2ğœŒÂ¯â„“1ğ›½for fair regularization method with group level (7) or sample level penalty (8)Â otherwiseğœŒÂ¯â„“1ğ›½for fair sample re-weighting method (9)Â otherwise\tilde{\beta}:=\begin{cases}(2\rho\overline{\ell}+1)\beta,~{}~{}~{}\text{for % fair regularization method with group level \eqref{eq:squared_group_loss_% penalty} or sample level penalty \eqref{eq:fair_loss_sample_level} }\\ (\rho\overline{\ell}+1)\beta,~{}~{}~{}\text{for fair sample re-weighting % method \eqref{eq:fair_reweight} }\end{cases}over~ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG := { start_ROW start_CELL ( 2 italic_Ï overÂ¯ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG + 1 ) italic_Î² , for fair regularization method with group level ( ) or sample level penalty ( ) end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ( italic_Ï overÂ¯ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG + 1 ) italic_Î² , for fair sample re-weighting method ( ) end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW

where â„“Â¯:=supğœ½,Zâ„“â¢(ğœ½;Z)assignÂ¯â„“subscriptsupremumğœ½ğ‘â„“ğœ½ğ‘\overline{\ell}:=\sup_{\boldsymbol{\theta},Z}\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)overÂ¯ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG := roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ , italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; italic_Z ). We can identify conditions under which a unique Fair-PS solution exists.

Proposition 5.1 (Existence of unique Fair-PS solution).

For a given population with initial distribution ğ’Ÿ(0)superscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}^{(0)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the proposed fair mechanism â„’fairsubscriptâ„’fair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with strength ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï, there is a unique Fair-PS solution if Ïµâ¢(1+Î²~/Î³)<1italic-Ïµ1~ğ›½ğ›¾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_Ïµ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG / italic_Î³ ) < 1. Moreover, (ğ’ŸfairPS,ğ›‰fairPS)subscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfairsubscriptsuperscriptğ›‰PSfair(\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{% \textsf{fair}})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is independent of the choice of repeated deployment schema.

Although the choice of repeated deployment schema does not affect the Fair-PS solution (ğ’ŸfairPS,ğœ½fairPS)subscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfairsubscriptsuperscriptğœ½PSfair(\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{% \textsf{fair}})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), it influences the convergence rate of the iterative algorithms as stated in Theorem 5.2.

Theorem 5.2 (Convergence of Fair-RRM).

Under conventional deployment schema, Algorithm 1 converges to the Fair-PS solution at a linear rate if Ïµâ¢(1+Î²~/Î³)<1italic-Ïµ1~ğ›½ğ›¾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_Ïµ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG / italic_Î³ ) < 1; under kğ‘˜kitalic_k-delayed deployment schema, Algorithm 1 converges to the Fair-PS solution at a linear rate for any kğ‘˜kitalic_k if Ïµâ¢(1+Î²~/Î³)<1âˆ’Ïµitalic-Ïµ1~ğ›½ğ›¾1italic-Ïµ\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1-\epsilonitalic_Ïµ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG / italic_Î³ ) < 1 - italic_Ïµ; Particularly, under delayed deployment schema when r=logâˆ’1â¡(1Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(ğ’²1â¢(ğ’Ÿ(0),ğ’Ÿ(1))Î´)ğ‘Ÿsuperscript11italic-Ïµsubscriptğ’²1superscriptğ’Ÿ0superscriptğ’Ÿ1ğ›¿r=\log^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)\log\left(\frac{\mathcal{W}_{1}(% \mathcal{D}^{(0)},\mathcal{D}^{(1)})}{\delta}\right)italic_r = roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ), Algorithm 1 converges to a radius Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ of the Fair-PS solution (i.e., â€–ğ›‰(t)âˆ’ğ›‰fairPSâ€–2â‰¤Î´subscriptnormsuperscriptğ›‰ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ›‰PSfair2ğ›¿\|\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\|_% {2}\leq\deltaâˆ¥ bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î´ and ğ’²1â¢(ğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ›‰(t)),ğ’ŸfairPS)â‰¤Î´subscriptğ’²1ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ›‰ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfairğ›¿\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}),\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}% _{\textsf{fair}})\leq\deltacaligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_Î´) in ğ’ªâ¢(log2â¡1Î´)ğ’ªsuperscript21ğ›¿\mathcal{O}(\log^{2}\frac{1}{\delta})caligraphic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) steps if Ïµâ¢(1+Î²~/Î³)<1italic-Ïµ1~ğ›½ğ›¾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_Ïµ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG / italic_Î³ ) < 1.

In AppendixÂ B.3, we extend the Algorithm 1 to practical scenarios when data distribution is inaccessible. We provide the algorithm fair repeated empirical risk minimization (Fair-RERM) where only limited data samples are available from ğ’Ÿ(t)superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and analyze its sample complexity in Theorem B.3.

Impacts of strength of fair mechanism ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï. Theorem 5.2 and B.3 show that repeatedly minimizing â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ(tâˆ’1),Ï)subscriptâ„’fairğœ½superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1ğœŒ\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï ) on evolving data sequence can lead the system converging to a Fair-PS solution. Note that ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï controls the strength of fairness and different ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï could result in different (ğœ½fairPS,ğ’ŸfairPS)subscriptsuperscriptğœ½PSfairsubscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfair(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{% \textsf{fair}})( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In conventional supervised learning with static data distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, it is trivial to see that larger ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï in â„’fairâ¢(ğœ½;ğ’Ÿ,Ï)subscriptâ„’fairğœ½ğ’ŸğœŒ\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_D , italic_Ï ) will lead to a fairer solution [6]. However, in SDPP with model-dependent distribution shifts, the impact of ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï on unfairness is less straightforward. Because both data distribution ğ’ŸfairPSsubscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfair\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and model ğœ½fairPSsubscriptsuperscriptğœ½PSfair\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depend on ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï, analyzing how group-wise disparity would change as ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï varies can be highly non-trivial and has not been studied in PP literature (Appendix D.4 provides more discussion).

Next, we initiate the study for fair mechanism in Eqn.Â (7) with group-level fairness penalty and rigorously show that the larger ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï can lead to smaller group-wise loss disparity at the Fair-PS solution. We will focus on a special case of user retention dynamics [19, 2] with two groups sâˆˆ{a,b}ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘s\in\{a,b\}italic_s âˆˆ { italic_a , italic_b }, where the group distribution ğ’Ÿssubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ \mathcal{D}_{s}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is fixed but the fraction ps(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes based on group loss â„’â¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿs)â„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{s})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) during repeated risk minimization process.

Assumption 5.3.

At each round, the group that is majority also experiences lower expected loss, i.e., argâ¡maxsâˆˆ{a,b}â¡pst=argâ¡minsâˆˆ{a,b}â¡â„’â¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿs)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘â„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ \arg\max_{s\in\{a,b\}}p_{s}^{t}=\arg\min_{s\in\{a,b\}}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{% \theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{s})roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Moreover, for any two models deployed on population ğ’Ÿ(t)superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the model with larger loss disparity â–³â„’(t)superscriptsubscriptâ–³â„’ğ‘¡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}â–³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT leads to higher group fraction disparity â–³p(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptâ–³ğ‘¡1ğ‘\triangle^{(t+1)}_{p}â–³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at time t+1ğ‘¡1t+1italic_t + 1.

Assumption 5.3 is natural: in fields such as recognition or recommendation systems, the minority group contributing less training data suffers from higher loss and has a lower retention rate.

Theorem 5.4 (Larger ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï leads to stronger fairness).

Denote Fair-PS solution (ğ›‰fairPSâ¢(Ï),ğ’ŸfairPSâ¢(Ï))subscriptsuperscriptğ›‰PSfairğœŒsubscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfairğœŒ\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\left(\rho\right),% \mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\left(\rho\right)\right)( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) ) as a function of Ïâ‰¥0ğœŒ0\rho\geq 0italic_Ï â‰¥ 0. Let â–³fair,â„’PSâ¢(Ï)subscriptsuperscriptâ–³PSfairâ„’ğœŒ\triangle^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair},\mathcal{L}}(\rho)â–³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair , caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) be the group-wise loss disparity of ğ›‰fairPSâ¢(Ï)subscriptsuperscriptğ›‰PSfairğœŒ\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\left(\rho\right)bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) evaluated over distribution ğ’ŸfairPSâ¢(Ï)subscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸPSfairğœŒ\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\left(\rho\right)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) as defined in Eqn.Â (4). Under Assumption 5.3, â–³fair,â„’PSâ¢(Ï)subscriptsuperscriptâ–³PSfairâ„’ğœŒ\triangle^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair},\mathcal{L}}(\rho)â–³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair , caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï ) is non-increasing in ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï.

6 Numerical Results

This section empirically evaluates the proposed methods on synthetic and real-world data (including credit data [4, 23] and MNIST data [24]) under semi-synthesized performative shifts. We run all experiments with multiple random seeds and visualize the standard error with the shaded area. Due to page limits, more experiments are presented in AppendixÂ C.

Performative Gaussian mean estimation. We generate a synthetic dataset of 10000100001000010000 samples from two groups sâˆˆ{a,b}ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘s\in\{a,b\}italic_s âˆˆ { italic_a , italic_b } with initial group fractions pa(0)=0.3,pb(0)=0.7formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘00.3superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘00.7p_{a}^{(0)}=0.3,p_{b}^{(0)}=0.7italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.3 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.7 and target values ya=0.3+Ïµ,yb=0.7+Ïµformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘0.3italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘0.7italic-Ïµy_{a}=0.3+\epsilon,y_{b}=0.7+\epsilonitalic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.3 + italic_Ïµ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.7 + italic_Ïµ, where Ïµâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,0.05)similar-toitalic-Ïµğ’©00.05\epsilon\sim\mathcal{N}(0,0.05)italic_Ïµ âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 0.05 ). We consider user retention dynamics where the group fraction ps(t+1)=â„›â¢(s,t)âˆ‘sâ€²âˆˆ{a,b}â„›â¢(sâ€²,t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1ğ‘ â„›ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘ğ‘â„›superscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘¡p^{(t+1)}_{s}=\frac{\mathcal{R}(s,t)}{\sum_{s^{\prime}\in\{a,b\}}\mathcal{R}(s% ^{\prime},t)}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG caligraphic_R ( italic_s , italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t ) end_ARG changes based on group-wise loss. Here â„›â¢(s,t)=(1âˆ’âˆ‘sâ€²âˆˆ{a,b}psâ€²min)Ã—12â¢(pst+â„’â¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿâˆ’s(t))â„’â¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿâˆ’s(t))+â„’â¢(ğœ½(t);ğ’Ÿs(t)))+psminâ„›ğ‘ ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘ â€²12superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡â„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡â„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡â„’superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ \mathcal{R}(s,t)=\left(1-\sum_{s^{\prime}\in\{a,b\}}p^{\min}_{s^{\prime}}% \right)\times\frac{1}{2}\left(p_{s}^{t}+\frac{\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^% {(t)};\mathcal{D}_{-s}^{(t)})}{\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{% D}_{-s}^{(t)})+\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)})}% \right)+p_{s}^{\min}caligraphic_R ( italic_s , italic_t ) = ( 1 - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) Ã— divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) + italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where psmin=0.02superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ 0.02p_{s}^{\min}=0.02italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.02 is the minimum group fraction that ensures the sensitivity of the transition mapping T is bounded, and âˆ’s={a,b}âˆ–sğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ -s=\{a,b\}\setminus s- italic_s = { italic_a , italic_b } âˆ– italic_s. We perform the mean estimation task and train multiple linear regression models using RERM and Fair-RERM, including regularization methods with group-level penalty (Fair-RERM-GLP), sample-level penalty (Fair-RERM-SLP) and sample re-weighting method (Fair-RERM-RW). We perform 30303030 rounds of empirical risk minimization on 7777 different random seeds. Fig. 2(a) illustrates the evolution of group-wise loss disparity â–³â„’(t)superscriptsubscriptâ–³â„’ğ‘¡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}â–³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Fig. 2(b) shows the evolution of the minority group fraction (i.e., the group with the lower fraction at the stable point). The blue lines in both figures demonstrate that the PS solution of the regular RERM has the highest unfairness and the most polarized group fractions, while the Fair-PS solution is fairer and the higher ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï results in stronger fairness, implying Fair-RERM is effective in mitigating polarization effects and unfairness. We also note that among all three methods, the sample re-weighting method (Fair-RERM-RW) seems to yield better fairness control than others under this setting.

Credit data retention dynamics with strategic behaviors. We use the Give me some credit data [23] consisting of features Xâˆˆâ„10ğ‘‹superscriptâ„10X\in\mathbb{R}^{10}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to measure individualsâ€™ creditworthiness Yâˆˆ{0,1}ğ‘Œ01Y\in\{0,1\}italic_Y âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } which has been widely used in performative prediction and strategic classification literature [4, 15]. We preprocessed the data similarly to Perdomo etÂ al. [4] and divided individuals into two groups sâˆˆ{a,b}ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘s\in\{a,b\}italic_s âˆˆ { italic_a , italic_b } based on the age attribute. Next, we assume there is a newly established credit rating agency performing RERM and Fair-RERM with logistic classification models to predict individualsâ€™ creditworthiness. Similar to the previous experiment, we assume the group-wise loss in round tğ‘¡titalic_t will affect the group fraction at t+1ğ‘¡1t+1italic_t + 1. Meanwhile, we assume there is a subset of features XsâˆˆXsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ ğ‘‹X_{s}\in Xitalic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_X which individuals can change strategically to Xsâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ â€²X_{s}^{\prime}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT based on the current model parameters Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸. Specifically, Xsâ€²=Xsâˆ’Ïµâ‹…Î¸ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ â€²subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ â‹…italic-Ïµsubscriptğœƒğ‘ X_{s}^{\prime}=X_{s}-\epsilon\cdot\theta_{s}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïµ â‹… italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Î¸ssubscriptğœƒğ‘ \theta_{s}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the subset of Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ with respect to Xssubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ X_{s}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ïµ=0.1italic-Ïµ0.1\epsilon=0.1italic_Ïµ = 0.1. With the dynamics involving both retention and strategic behaviors, we can visualize the dynamics of unfairness under RERM and Fair-RERM in Fig. 3. All results demonstrate the effectiveness of our methods. The regularization method with sample level penalty (Fair-RERM-SLP) seems to be more effective under this setting.

Performative MNIST classification. We next consider MNIST data [24] consisting of handwritten digits images. We randomly select 1000 images as the training set and divide them into 2 groups, where the first group contains all images with digits from 00 to 4444 and the second includes digits from 5555 to 9999. We consider the same group fraction dynamics as before with psmin=0.1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ 0.1p_{s}^{\min}=0.1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.1 for both groups. Using a 2-layer MLP (the loss function violates conditions in Lemma 2.4) for risk minimization, we perform RERM and Fair-RERM for 50505050 rounds. Fig.Â 4(a) and 4(b) verify that Fair-RERM can still improve fairness at the PS solution. Both plots demonstrate that unfairness is the largest without fairness interventions and Fair-RERM is more effective with larger ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï. Unlike the experiments on synthetic and credit data, this set of experiments does not have a convergence guarantee because conditions for theorems are violated under 2-layer MLP, e.g., the black and red lines (Ï=0.3ğœŒ0.3\rho=0.3italic_Ï = 0.3) of Fair-RERM-RW and Fair-RERM-GLP are unstable. However, the results suggest that our fairness mechanisms may still be useful in practice with deep learning models.

7 Conclusions & Societal Impacts

Our work reveals the unfairness issues of the PS solutions of PP. We then propose novel fairness-aware algorithms to find Fair-PS solutions with the convergence holds under mild assumptions, which will facilitate trustworthy machine learning since PP has broad applications on human-related decisions ranging from college admission and loan approval to hiring practice. Meaningful future directions include relaxing the conditions for the convergence of fairness mechanisms or expanding the mechanisms to deep learning settings.

Appendix A Related Works

Performative Prediction. Proposed by Perdomo etÂ al. [4], Performative prediction focuses on machine learning problems where the model deployments influence the data distribution, and the common application scenarios include strategic classification [1, 25, 26, 27] and predictive policing [28]. Perdomo etÂ al. [4] formulated the problem and proposed repeated risk minimization (RRM) to ensure the convergence of model parameters to a stable point under a set of sufficient and necessary conditions. Mendler-DÃ¼nner etÂ al. [29] presented convergence results on stochastic performative optimization. Subsequent work either strived to relax the convergence condition [30, 31] or develop methods to ensure the convergence to performative optimal points under special cases [32, 33]. Brown etÂ al. [5] extended performative prediction to stateful settings where the current data distribution is determined by both the previous states and the deployed model. For more related works on PP, we refer to this survey [34].

Long-term fairness. There is a large line of work on long-term fairness in machine learning, where we mainly refer to distributionally robust optimization (DRO) [12, 13] and soft fair regularizers [35, 36, 37]. DRO refers to the optimization problem where the loss is minimized on the worst-case distribution around current data distribution [12, 13], while soft fair regularizers are often used in traditional fair optimization frameworks to penalize unfairness. Only a few pieces of literature touched on fairness problems under performative prediction settings. [38, 39, 17, 40] focused on long-term fairness settings under strategic classification similar to Example 3.2. Zezulka and Genin [14] pointed out fairness issues in performative prediction and formulated it within causal graphs. Hu and Zhang [15] also used causality-based models to formulate and ensure short-term and long-term fairness in performative prediction, incurring strong assumptions and expensive computational costs. Raab etÂ al. [8] studied a special case where only the agentsâ€™ retention rates are performative. Peet-Pare etÂ al. [21] proposed to use distributionally robust optimization (DRO) to promote fairness in performative prediction, but they proposed assumptions that are hard to verify and can not be derived from other commonly accepted assumptions in PP.

Appendix B Further Elaboration on the Concepts

Here we include the notation table and a Venn diagram to help the readers better understand the technical details of our paper.

B.1 Notation Table

B.2 Venn Diagram of Concepts in PP

We present a Venn diagram of different PP cases in Figure 5. Within the broad concept of PP, we specifically characterize 3 practical concepts in real-world problems, namely the (1) state-dependent performative shifts, (2) performative retention dynamics, and (3) performative distribution shifts. These concepts represent different dimensions to partition the PP problems.

Performative Retention Dynamics (PRD).

Previous works that study long-term fairness [2, 40] mostly assume there to be model-dependent retention rate/population fraction pssubscriptğ‘ğ‘ p_{s}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT changes, which can all be formulated as PRD problems. Recommendation systems are typical application scenarios of SDPP and PRD since the population fraction in the next iteration depends on both the current population and the current model. The better recommendation model captures a certain user groupâ€™s interest, the more likely this user group will have high retention rate.

Example B.1.

(User retention) Suppose two demographic groups a,bğ‘ğ‘a,bitalic_a , italic_b each follow a static distribution ğ’Ÿasubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘\mathcal{D}_{a}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ’Ÿbsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘\mathcal{D}_{b}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but their fraction in the population changes over time, and thus the overall data distribution is dynamic. Specifically, let psmâ¢iâ¢nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›p_{s}^{min}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be control variables to limit the minimum fraction of group sğ‘ sitalic_s, and their retention rate is determined by a retention function Ï€sâ¢(ğ›‰(t))subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ superscriptğ›‰ğ‘¡\pi_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then we have

ps(t):=ps(tâˆ’1)â¢Ï€sâ¢(ğœ½(t))+psmâ¢iâ¢nâˆ‘sâ€²(psâ€²(tâˆ’1)â¢Ï€sâ€²â¢(ğœ½(t))+psâ€²mâ¢iâ¢n),ğ’Ÿ(t)=âˆ‘sps(t)â¢ğ’Ÿs,formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1ğ‘ subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘ â€²subscriptğœ‹superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ p^{(t)}_{s}:=\frac{p^{(t-1)}_{s}\pi_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})+p_{s}^{min}% }{\sum_{s^{\prime}}(p^{(t-1)}_{s^{\prime}}\pi_{s^{\prime}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}% ^{(t)})+p_{s^{\prime}}^{min})},~{}~{}\mathcal{D}^{(t)}=\sum_{s}p^{(t)}_{s}% \mathcal{D}_{s},italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - which can be modeled by PP in the SDPP setting.

Performative Distribution Shifts (PDS).

In this paper, PDS specifically means in each group, the data distribution ğ’Ÿssubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ \mathcal{D}_{s}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT shifts with the decision models, e.g., in strategic classification, users strategically manipulate their features for better decision outcomes. In recommendation systems, where creators strategically manipulate their features for better decision outcomes from the model [1], and usersâ€™ interests can be shifted by the recommended items.

We present a practical example of PP in addition to the one in the main article.

Example B.2.

(Partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP) as PDS [40]) The population fractions of the two groups pssubscriptğ‘ğ‘ p_{s}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are static, i.e., ğ’Ÿ(t)=âˆ‘spsâ¢ğ’Ÿs(t)superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}=\sum_{s}p_{s}\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, but the feature distribution changes with the deployed decision model, and such changes follow a POMDP as shown in Figure 6.

Specifically, within each group, there are two sub-populations, qualified and disqualified, e.g., the qualified sub-population in group ağ‘aitalic_a satisfies y=1,s=aformulae-sequenceğ‘¦1ğ‘ ğ‘y=1,s=aitalic_y = 1 , italic_s = italic_a. Each sub-population has a static distribution, ğ’Ÿs,ysubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¦\mathcal{D}_{s,y}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but each groupâ€™s distribution is dynamic and determined by

The POMDP assumes the decision model and the sensitive attribute jointly determine the distribution of the true label distribution at the next time step, and we have

B.3 Fair-RERM

Here we provide the algorithm for the Fair-RERM class and the results of its sample complexity.

Theorem B.3 (Convergence of fair-RERM).

Suppose âˆƒÎ±>1,Î¼>0formulae-sequenceğ›¼1ğœ‡0\exists\alpha>1,\mu>0âˆƒ italic_Î± > 1 , italic_Î¼ > 0 such that âˆ«â„meÎ¼â¢|x|Î±â¢Zâ¢ğ‘‘xsubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘’ğœ‡superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ‘differential-dğ‘¥\int_{\mathbb{R}^{m}}e^{\mu|x|^{\alpha}}Zdxâˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ | italic_x | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Z italic_d italic_x is finite âˆ€Zâˆˆâ–³â¢(ğ’µ)for-allğ‘â–³ğ’µ\forall Z\in\triangle(\mathcal{Z})âˆ€ italic_Z âˆˆ â–³ ( caligraphic_Z ). For a given convergence radius Î´âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¿01\delta\in(0,1)italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), take nt=ğ’ªâ¢(logâ¡(t/p)(Ïµâ¢(1+Î²~/Î³)â¢Î´)m)subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ’ªğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ1~ğ›½ğ›¾ğ›¿ğ‘šn_{t}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\log(t/p)}{(\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)% \delta)^{m}}\right)italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log ( italic_t / italic_p ) end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_Ïµ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG / italic_Î³ ) italic_Î´ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) samples at tğ‘¡titalic_t. B.4 General guidance of designing fairness objectives under the SDPP setting

The key to designing a fairness objective while ensuring the convergence of the iterative algorithm is to ensure the convexity of the fairness penalty. Example 4.2 shows that group loss variance cannot preserve the convexity of â„’fairsubscriptâ„’fair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so it fails to be a plausible objective. This implies that each penalty term in terms of P=gâ¢(â„’)ğ‘ƒğ‘”â„’P=g(\mathcal{L})italic_P = italic_g ( caligraphic_L ) where the convexity of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is ensured can be a fairness objective. However, it can still be highly non-trivial to design a fair objective in this form due to the following reasons: (i) it is hard to design an objective as interpretable as the ones we mentioned in Section 4. The squared loss as a penalty term is well-motivated and directly penalizes the groups/samples with the higher losses; (ii) It becomes more difficult to obtain the concrete parameters for the convergence guarantee. For example, â„“Â¯Â¯â„“\bar{\ell}overÂ¯ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG in Section 5 becomes the upper bound of âˆ‚gâˆ‚â„“ğ‘”â„“\frac{\partial g}{\partial\ell}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_g end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ roman_â„“ end_ARG and this may be hard to obtain and interpret. Overall, we see the formulations in Section 4 as more appropriate choices.

B.5 Only Measure Fairness at PS Solution

We provide an example to illustrate that fairness is not guaranteed even if we ensure instantaneous fairness without stability being achieved.

Example B.4.

(Fairness violation due to performative shifts) Consider a binary strategic classification problem with two groups a,bğ‘ğ‘a,bitalic_a , italic_b and is a threshold model hÎ¸â¢(X)=ğŸ™â¢{Xâ‰¥Î¸}subscriptâ„ğœƒğ‘‹1ğ‘‹ğœƒh_{\theta}(X)=\mathbbm{1}\{X\geq\theta\}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) = blackboard_1 { italic_X â‰¥ italic_Î¸ }. pa,pbsubscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{a},p_{b}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are fixed and both groups satisfy â„™â¢(Y(t)=1)=minâ¡{0,maxâ¡{X(t),1}}â„™superscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡10superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡1\mathbb{P}(Y^{(t)}=1)=\min\{0,\max\{X^{(t)},1\}\}blackboard_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 ) = roman_min { 0 , roman_max { italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 1 } }, and the transitions satisfy X(t)=X(0)+(0.1+0.1â‹…ğŸâ¢{s=a})â¢Î¸(t)superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘‹00.1â‹…0.11ğ‘ ğ‘superscriptğœƒğ‘¡X^{(t)}=X^{(0)}+(0.1+0.1\cdot\boldsymbol{1}\{s=a\})\theta^{(t)}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( 0.1 + 0.1 â‹… bold_1 { italic_s = italic_a } ) italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT but do not result in any changes in labels. If at t=0ğ‘¡0t=0italic_t = 0, both groups have features X(0)superscriptğ‘‹0X^{(0)}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT subject to uniform distribution on [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], then any Î¸=0.5ğœƒ0.5\theta=0.5italic_Î¸ = 0.5 satisfies accuracy parity. However, at t=1ğ‘¡1t=1italic_t = 1, group ağ‘aitalic_a has a shifted distribution, resulting in Î¸=0.5ğœƒ0.5\theta=0.5italic_Î¸ = 0.5 to be unfair.

Appendix C Additional Experiments

All experiments are run on the CPU of a Macbook Pro with Apple M1 Pro chip and 16GB memory. We use Python 3.9 for all tasks. For datasets, Yann LeCun and Corinna Cortes hold the copyright of MNIST, which is a derivative work from original NIST datasets. MNIST dataset is made available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 license; the credit dataset has been published by Kaggle [23]; In Appendix C.1, we visualize the convergence of performative loss for all the above experiments. In Appendix C.3, we perform experiments on a performative Gaussian data classification task. In Appendix C.2, we conduct experiments on 3 groups. In Appendix C.4, we visualize the unconvergence of the fairness penalty using group loss variance as a complementary to Example 4.2; Finally, we examine the k-delayed schema on all our fairness mechanisms on Credit data in Appendix C.5 and obtain the similar results.

C.1 Model Convergence in Main Experiments

In this section, we provide visualizations of the convergence of performative loss for all experiments of the main paper in Fig. 12. Importantly, Fig. 12(d) demonstrates the unconvergence of Fair-RERM-RW and Fair-RERM-GLP when Ï=0.3ğœŒ0.3\rho=0.3italic_Ï = 0.3.
